comment.author: 31990443@N04
comment._content:
"covered everything"?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Hi jorge dragon, These are lantern slides -- they were used in a projector for slide shows in the early 20th century. Some good info on lantern slides here. There's a frame around the image that usually has some information written on it. You can capture this by doing 2 scans (one reflective, one transmittive) and then stitching them together in PhotoShop. Takes a LOT of time and we had thousands of slides, so we just typed the information into the database instead. Sometimes it's hard to read, though, and and sometimes places had different names 100 years ago. Deb Wythe

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
By "covered everything" I meant "we included all of the information" (all of the different names of the aqueduct).
DW

comment.author: 31990443@N04
comment._content:
Excuse me Deb Wythe, but the position in map marked after Mafoso comment is wrong.

Maybe it's because of automatic confidence in the 2.0 world, or to support the participation itself, but It seems that Brooklyn Museum have not bothered to check on the map.

The geolocalization offered by Mafoso, as it appears in your Flickr mapping image, is the center of the city of Tarragona, and the aqueduct is, as written above, near 3 kms north from it. You can check the first comment and it's link; you will see the roman aqueduct and its own shadow over the pines.

Thanks again for your commitment with the disemination of information.
